Award.AwardTitle: NEON Science Summit: Initiating grassroots research communities through an 'unconference'; Summer/Fall; Boulder, Colorado
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funding is provided to the University of Colorado - Boulder for a workshop intended to assemble users of NEON data in an effort to stimulate research collaborations across NEON data themes and initiate the building of a 'NEON User Community.' An actively engaged NEON user community will stimulate and coordinate wider community interest around the research use and wider societal benefits of the Observatory.

A workshop utilizing the 'unconference' model aims to have participants identify near- and long-term collaborative opportunities to utilize NEON infrastructure and data. Both NEON infrastructure and data will provide the context for the generation of novel, exciting, collaborative research. The workshop will contribute to the building of the community of NEON users. The participant recruitment plan presented enhances the assembly of a diverse group of NEON users by targeting different career stages, research foci, and types of academic institutions, among other demographic traits. The organizers for this 'unconference' will expand participation beyond the 100 selected attendees by encouraging remote attendance. Essentially, the workshop seeks to assemble current users of NEON and provide the foundation for building the community of future users.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is an entirely new type of entity for the ecological community, presenting unprecedented opportunities for advancing scientific discovery and informing resource management. The public availability of rigorous, coordinated continental-scale data lifts some of the logistical barriers that have previously constrained the scientific questions that can be addressed in ecology, and the analytical approaches that can be used. We saw the need to convene the community to motivate ecologists who are poised to work with NEON data, bringing macroscale scientific ideas, appropriate skill sets, and energy for collaboration. The main outcome from this work was the successful hosting of the first NEON Science Summit in 2019 at the University of Colorado Boulder. To summarize some of the main findings from NEON Science Summit, we wrote a guest editorial in Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment (https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/fee.2152).

One of our specific objectives was to engage a diverse community of NEON users. Summit participants spanned research areas and career stages but this effort was focused on supporting early-career researchers who are increasingly integrating NEON data into their research. The Summit steering committee represented a diversity of geographies, career stages, content areas, and institutions, including Metropolitan State University of Denver, a primarily undergraduate-serving institution, and Oglala Lakota College, which hosts one of the largest undergraduate science programs among all Tribal colleges in the U.S. Further, the steering committee used the workshop as an opportunity to scope an appropriate structure and growth trajectory for a persistent grassroots NEON Research Community to enable communication and collaboration, as well as community feedback for NEON operations. The workshop mobilized a network of researchers who eagerly embrace data-intensive research and will actively pursue new initiatives in open collaboration. To showcase this, a special feature in the journal Ecosphere will be published online in 2021 that includes ~15 manuscripts, most of which came from work that originated during the Summit. Many of these manuscripts are in review now and several have already been accepted for publication. The steering committee for the NEON Science Summit led the writing on one of these manuscripts entitled “Harnessing the NEON Data Revolution to Advance Open Environmental Science with a Diverse and Data-Capable Community” that is currently in revision.
